thread.title: Brexit: The week that changed the political landscape of Britain forever
thread.title_full: Brexit: The week that changed the political landscape of Britain forever

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Brexit: The week that changed the political landscape of Britain forever
text:
Political Editor Jonathan Walker looks back on a week that made history as we come to terms with Britain's EU exit Shares Get daily news by email Daniel Leal-Olivas/PA Wire Prime Minister David Cameron speaks outside 10 Downing Street, London, where he announced his resignation after Britain voted to leave the European Union 
It was the most important week in British politics since the Second World War. 
Our political editor Jon Walker takes a look back at five days that changed the political landscape of the North East - and the UK. Monday 
With just days to go before the nation voted on whether to quit the European Union , MPs were gathered in Westminster to pay tribute to their colleague Jo Cox following her senseless murder. 
It was a moving event, viewed from the public gallery by Mrs Cox’s husband, Brendan, and their two tiny children, three-year-old daughter Lejla and son Cuillin, five. Yui Mok/PA Wire Labour MP Jo Cox 
Some Labour MPs were in tears. 
But while everyone was sincere in their desire to set campaigning aside for the day, the EU referendum battle continued. 
Sayeeda Warsi, the former Chair of the Conservative Party, had announced she was switching her allegiance from the “Leave” campaign to “Remain”. 
The statement prompted mockery from Leave activists, who said they never realised she was on their side to start with. 
But the reason she gave for switching sides struck a nerve. She said she was appalled by the “hate and xenophobia” of the remain campaign. 
It followed the publication of a poster by UKIP leader Nigel Farage which showed a queue of people of Arab appearance and the words “Breaking Point”. 
The poster appeared to suggest that the UK was set to be invaded by hordes of refugees from Syria and elsewhere, and this was somehow the EU’s fault. 
It was widely condemned as racist. George Osborne , the Chancellor and a Remain campaigner, said it had echoes of 1930s fascist propaganda. 
For the official Leave campaign - which did not include Mr Farage - it was an embarrassment. Lewis Whyld/PA Wire Justice Secretary Michael Gove 
Conservatives Michael Gove and Boris Johnson, and Labour MP Gisela Stuart, were leading the Vote Leave campaign. Mr Farage had gone his own way and joined a separate, unofficial campaign. 
But that didn’t stop some Remain campaigners from using the poster to suggest that the entire Remain campaign was intolerant, anti-immigrant and perhaps vaguely racist. 
Mr Farage complained that his side in the Referendum campaign had been depicted as the “bad guys” following the “isolated, horrific incident” in which Jo Cox was killed, as he spoke at a rally in Gateshead. Tuesday 
There was a sense that the tide was turning. Opinion polls the previous week had suggested Britain was set to vote to leave the EU - but the Remain campaign was staging an effective fightback. 
Prime Minister David Cameron delivered a speech outside Number 10, but along with other Remain Conservatives he was happy for Labour to grab most of the spotlight. Their thinking was that the key to winning the vote was convincing Labour voters that staying in the EU was in their interest. 
And Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn delivered a speech claiming that leaving the EU would lead to a “bonfire of employment rights”. John Linton/PA Wire Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn 
However, he also warned that the EU needed reform - suggesting that he wasn’t a huge fan of the EU as it exists today. 
Labour’s Shadow Business Secretary, Angela Eagle MP and former Chancellor of the Exchequer Alistair Darling were in the North East to make the economic case for Britain staying in the European Union. 
Speaking at the Hewlett Packard Enterprise site in North Tyneside, Lord Darling said that “the stakes couldn’t be higher” 
The big set-piece BBC TV debate, at Wembley arena, saw London mayor Sadiq Khan, a Remain supporter, tell Leave campaigners such as Boris Johnson: “You should know better”. 
But Mr Johnson delivered a passionate and eloquent speech in favour of leaving the EU at the end of the programme. Wednesday 
A final day of frantic activity saw political leaders from past and present wheeled out to make a last-minute plea to voters. 
David Cameron warned Brexit would be “bad for jobs” - but his predecessor as Prime Minister, former Tory leader John Major, was also on the campaign trail. 
Jeremy Corbyn said the NHS would be under threat if we left, while former Labour leader Gordon Brown also called for a Remain vote. 
And Lib Dem leader Tim Farron was joined by his predecessor Paddy Ashdown to back EU membership. 
A bizarre battle broke out over which side of the debate famous footballers were on. 
The Leave campaign said former Newcastle United footballer John Barnes backed their campaign - only for him to state that he was backing Remain. Thursday 
Polling day, and campaigners were hard at work trying to ensure their supporters actually went out to vote. 
It’s the same sort of operation we see in general elections - including lots of knocking on doors - but the remain campaign had an advantage here. 
They had the official Labour Party machinery to help them, while the Lib Dems and Greens are also backing Remain (the Conservative Party is officially neutral in this campaign). Simon Greener Polling stations across the region for the EU referendum St Andrews Newcastle 
However the Leave campaign didn’t have any party machine to help them. 
The remain campaign was confident, when the polls closed at 10pm. 
And as counting began, UKIP leader Nigel Farage admitted that he thought Britain may have voted narrowly to remain in the EU. Friday 
The first place to finish counting votes and announce a result was Gibraltar, which was involved in the referendum despite not being part of the UK. 
But Newcastle was the first place in the UK to make an announcement, at about five minutes past midnight. 
And immediately, the remain campaign knew something was wrong. 
They’d won - but with a tiny majority. 
Just 50.7% of Newcastle voters wanted the UK to remain a member of the European Union while 49.3% wanted to leave. 
The experts had expected it to be better than that for the remain campaign. 
As time went by it became clear that other parts of the North East had voted overwhelmingly to leave. 
And most part of the UK - with the exception of Scotland, Northern Ireland and London - had done the same. 
The optimism of the remain campaign faded. British Prime Minister David Cameron resigns on the steps of 10 Downing Street 
And it slowly became clear to the leave campaign that they had won. 
At around 4.45 am, the BBC announced that the UK had voted to leave the EU. 
There were still more votes to be counted, but it wasn’t possible for Remain to win, the BBC’s analysts had concluded. 
A few hours later, David Cameron made his announcement outside Downing Street. 
He was quitting. 
We don’t know who will replace him. In fact, we don’t know very much about what the future holds at all. 
But one way or another, this week began a new chapter in the history of our country. Saturday 
Britain wakes to a new political climate - but where do we go from here? More on the EU Referendum
